node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Jade | Special Educator on July 29, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Trauma is the same thing as Post-traumatic stress disorder Misconceptions about trauma @what.is.mental.illness You have to be physically hurt to experience trauma Fight or Flight are the only responses to trauma Trauma is only the really big things, like physical and sexual abuse We have control over our fight/ flight/freeze response Struggling with trauma is sign of weakness If force myselfto stop thinking about the trauma, it will go away You only experience trauma after a life- threatening event'.

node.text:
Leave a YES in the comments if you learned something new about trauma today! 🤍

When trauma was first conceptualized, it was defined as a ‘’catastrophic event outside the usual human experience”. At the time, people linked trauma with specific events such as war, torture, and the Holocaust. However, more research on neurobiology, the human experience, and even current events have open the door to a broader conversation about how many of us are truly exposed to trauma.

So, what is trauma? And who gets to decide?👇🏼

Trauma is any event or experience that overwhelms the brain’s ability to cope, and shapes our beliefs or behaviors going forward. Even more simply, it is anything that causes an individual deep, lasting distress during and/or after the event has taken place. Ultimately, trauma is less about what happened, and more about one’s subjective experience of it. 😵‍💫

Thanks to experts in the field of research, we know a lot more about trauma then we used to. Dr. Peter Levine in his book Waking the Tiger writes, “What most people don’t know is that many seemingly benign situations can be traumatic… The consequences of trauma can be widespread and hidden.”

Here are a few common misconceptions about trauma, debunked. The explanations are in the comments 🙌🏼

List any others misconceptions about trauma that you ever heard! 

Sources: Caption from “A Therapist Debunks Common Misconceptions About Trauma” | Psychology Today | Health & Wellness | Live Free Counseling 

✨ Follow @what.is.mental.illness for 
more mental health tools & resources 
_________________

Link in bio #Ad'.
Photo by Jade | Special Educator on July 28, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'WHAT DOES GASLIGHTING SOUND LIKE? AND HOW TO RESPOND @what.is.mental.illness'.

node.text:
Put a ❤️ in the comments if any of these phrases sound familiar.

Gaslighting isn’t always easy to recognize, especially since it often starts small, and other behaviors can sometimes seem similar. True gaslighting develops into a repeated pattern of manipulation. The person gaslighting you generally wants you to doubt yourself and depend on their version of reality. So, someone who offers a different opinion than yours, even in a rude or critical way, isn’t necessarily gaslighting.

People sometimes feel convinced of their own knowledge and insist they’re right, even when evidence suggests otherwise. Insisting “You’re wrong! I know what I’m talking about” isn’t necessarily polite, but it’s generally not gaslighting if they aren’t trying to manipulate you.

People can also gaslight unintentionally. “I don’t have time to listen to this” or “Don’t you think you’re overreacting?” may not be helpful responses, but they don’t always mean the other person wants to manipulate you.
When considering whether someone is trying to gaslight you, take stock of your feelings, not just their actions. You can take a look at my previous post about gaslighting for more informations. 🧠

Gaslighting works because it confuses you and shakes your confidence. If you show that the behavior doesn’t bother you, the person trying to gaslight you may decide it isn’t worth the struggle. In addition to lies and misdirection, gaslighting often involves criticism and insults. Calling these out — calmly and politely — shows them you won’t accept the behavior. Don’t be afraid to speak up, since making others aware of the situation gives them more incentive to leave you alone. If they continue challenging you, don’t get drawn into conflict. Arguing can lead to further tension and put you in a position where you’re more vulnerable to manipulation. By refusing to argue, you protect yourself and maintain control over the situation. 🗣

Sources : Caption from Healthline : Think You're Being Gaslit? Here's How to Respond. | Psychology Group 

✨ Follow @what.is.mental.illness for 
more mental health tools & resources 
_________________

#panic #panicattack

node.text:
Put a 💜 in the comments if you’ve ever been gaslighted. #youarenotalone

What is gaslighting?👇🏼

Gaslighting is a form of emotional abuse that's seen in abusive relationships. It's the act of manipulating a person by forcing them to question their thoughts, memories, and the events occurring around them. A victim of gaslighting can be pushed so far that they question their own sanity.

What are the impacts?👇🏼

The long-term effects of gaslighting can be extremely damaging to one’s mental health. The impacts may include anxiety, depression, trauma, low self-esteem, increased self-doubt, difficulty trusting your own judgment, second-guessing reality or your memories and so much more. 

✍🏼 Comment below : What does gaslighting feel like for you? What else would you like to add? 

Sources : Healthline | Psychology Group | 

 Follow @what.is.mental.illness for 
more mental health tools & resources 
_________________

node.text:
What kind of situations trigger your social anxiety? #youarenotalone

What is social anxiety disorder? 👇🏼

Social anxiety disorder (also called social phobia) is a mental health condition characterized by an intense, persistent fear of being watched and judged by others. This fear can affect work, school, and your other day-to-day activities. It involves intense fear of certain social situations (especially situations that are unfamiliar or in which you feel you’ll be watched or evaluated by others). 

For people with social anxiety disorder, anxiety is often triggered by specific social situations, such as speaking in public or even meeting new people at a party. You may have one or multiple triggers, which is why learning to identify your personal triggers can help you avoid or better cope with your social anxiety disorder.

Please that Social anxiety disorder may present itself differently from a person to another. Two different people with the same disorder won’t necessarily have the same symptoms nor triggers! Your experiences are still valid. 💜

Source : Check out Social Anxiety Disorder 
at Helpguide.org | Verywellmind for more infos!

✨ Follow @what.is.mental.illness for 
more mental health tools & resources 
_________________

node.text:
Put a ❤️ in the comments if you’ve ever experienced dissociation. #youarenotalone

Many people may experience dissociation (dissociate) during their life. If you dissociate, you may feel disconnected from yourself and the world around you. For example, you may feel detached from your body or feel as though the world around you is unreal. Remember, everyone’s experience of dissociation is different.
Dissociation is one way the mind copes with too much stress, such as during a traumatic event. It can also be related to many different mental health conditions. 
Experiences of dissociation can last for a relatively short time (hours or days) or for much longer (weeks, months and even years).

Dissociation can be experienced in lots of different ways :
👉🏼 Having difficulty remembering personal information (dissociative amnesia)
👉🏼 Travelling to a different location or taking on a new identity (dissociative fugue)
👉🏼 Feeling like the world around you is unreal (derealization)
👉🏼 Feeling like you're looking at yourself from the outside (depersonalization)
👉🏼 Feeling your identity shift and change (identity alteration)
👉🏼 Difficulty defining what kind of person you are (identify confusion)

👇🏼 Comment below : How does a dissociative episode feel like for you? 

PART 2 entire made by @what.is.mental.illness ‘s community ❤️‍🔥 A special thank you for all your answers, it’s been a real pleasure to pass the mic. 🎙 The purpose of this project is to give people who experience dissociation the space to be heard!

Source : Check out Dissociation and dissociative disorders at Mind.org for more infos!

✨ Follow @what.is.mental.illness for 
more mental health tools & resources 
_________________

Photo by Jade | Special Educator in Montreal, Quebec with @the.chronic.couple. May be an image of text that says 'How to support Autistic adults @what.is.mental.illnessx @the.chronic.couple Please don't believe the stereotypes. Each autistic person is different. Expand autistic support networks beyond childhood. Do not speak for us and take the initiative to educate yourself. #actuallyautistic. is great place start. Stop treating us like we need to be fixed. Autism is not disease. Please respect us and pay us for our labor. Understand that some days we may mask our autistic traits more than others. We are still autistic. Listen to us and take our needs and accommodations seriously. Don't infantilize us and be patient when we are struggling.'.

node.text:
There are many things you can do to help an autistic person overcome their challenges. These tips can help get you started! 📖

But first, what is Autism exactly? 

👉🏼 Autism is a developmental difference characterized by challenges with social interaction and communication, and by restricted and repetitive behaviors. Autistic people may communicate, interact, behave, and learn in ways that are different from most people. That is called neurodivergence 🌈

Remember that autism is a spectrum which means each autistic person is different, with their own challenges and needs.

By educating yourself about autism, you’II be better prepared and you’II feel more confident when interacting with an 
autistic person. 

What’s one question you have about autism you’d like us to answer? 🧠

👇🏼Comment below: To all the amazing autistic people out here, what make YOU feel supported? Tag your loved ones to let them know!

🎨💗 Collaboration with @the.chronic.couple

✨ Follow @what.is.mental.illness for 
more mental health tools & resources 
_________________

Put a ❤️ in the comments if you’ve ever experienced dissociation. #youarenotalone

Many people may experience dissociation (dissociate) during their life. If you dissociate, you may feel disconnected from yourself and the world around you. For example, you may feel detached from your body or feel as though the world around you is unreal. Remember, everyone’s experience of dissociation is different.
Dissociation is one way the mind copes with too much stress, such as during a traumatic event. It can also be related to many different mental health conditions. 
Experiences of dissociation can last for a relatively short time (hours or days) or for much longer (weeks, months and even years).

Dissociation can be experienced in lots of different ways :
👉🏼 Having difficulty remembering personal information (dissociative amnesia)
👉🏼 Travelling to a different location or taking on a new identity (dissociative fugue)
👉🏼 Feeling like the world around you is unreal (derealization)

Photo shared by Jade | Special Educator on July 15, 2021 tagging @treatmyocd. May be an image of text that says 'Understanding what OCD is not @what.is.mental.illness !!!! Wanting things to be clean, neat and tidy Wanting things to be done meti- culously Collecting things such as coins or stamps CRAYOLA Wanting things Wanting to perfectly aligned, color-coordinate and organized everything Being drawn to a particular area of interest'.

node.text:
A tiny guide to things OCD is not 📖

People use the terms ‘obsessive’ and ‘compulsive’ incorrectly, it leads to misunderstanding about OCD and belittles and trivialises the true suffering that the disorder can bring.
 
Yes, some of these behaviors can be compulsions for some OCD subtypes but I am not talking about this in this post. Here, I am talking about people who clearly do not live with OCD and would say something like “I’m so OCD for wanting things clean and neat”. I am talking about people who LOVE to do these things and enjoy them because they WANT to do them. People with OCD experience anxiety and distress from these behaviors. Once again, this is not the point. The point is to mention that OCD is not an adjective or a synonym for these behaviors. Obsessions and compulsions have to get to the point where they are affecting your daily life before they can be fully diagnosed as OCD. Obsessions and compulsions have to be time-consuming, distressing and—as is the case with any mental health condition—impacting functioning.

To help you learn if you have the condition and access effective therapy, I’ve partnered with NOCD. NOCD’s mission is to end the suffering caused by OCD. To find out if you’re struggling with OCD schedule a live face-to-face video session with one of NOCD’s licensed therapists. During their first session, your therapist will give you a comprehensive diagnostic assessment to help you understand if OCD is impacting your life. You can book a free call with their care team if you have any questions about treatment using the link in their bio! #ocd #nocd #ocdtherapy #erptherapy

Source : What’s not OCD | OCD UK

✨ Follow @what.is.mental.illness for 
more mental health tools & resources 
_________________

node.text:
Hit the SAVE button 📩 to try one of these next time you find yourself anxious or stressed!

List any questions to challenge negative thoughts in the comments that help you most! (Listed here or other) 💗🙂👇🏼

I’m reposting this tonight because I had to do some modifications concerning the last slide ("Am I paying attention only to the black side of things). One of my followers made me realize that this phrase is harmful to the Black Community. I thought it was important to acknowledge my mistake and apologize to everyone. I want you to know that it wasn’t my intention at all but I promise I will be careful about this in the future. Once again, I am sorry. 🤍

Source :
Challenge Negative Thinking | Anxiety Canada

✨ Follow @what.is.mental.illness for 
more mental health tools & resources 
_________________

node.text:
Put a 🧡 in the comments if you can relate!

Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a neurodevelomental disorder that can cause above-normal levels of hyperactive and impulsive behaviors. Both adults and children can have ADHD. It’s a diagnosis the American Psychiatric Association (APA) recognizes. A wide range of behaviors are associated with ADHD. They are not all written in this post but some  of the more common are there. 

To make ADHD diagnoses more consistent, the APA has grouped the condition into three categories, or types. These types are predominantly inattentive, predominantly hyperactivity-impulsive, and a combination of both.

Combined hyperactive-impulsive and inattentive type is the most common type of ADHD. People with this combined type of ADHD display both inattentive and hyperactive symptoms. These include an inability to pay attention, a tendency toward impulsiveness, and above-normal levels of activity and energy.

If you want to know why I draw Tigger, keep reading 👉🏼I’ve always loved Tigger. I feel like we’ve always have had a lot in common. We are literally the same. He’s exactly like I’ve always been : easily distracted, hyperactive, impulsive *(way too much). My inability to rest is impressive. When I’m happy or excited, I jump everywhere just like Tigger 😂 I talk too much and I’m really loud. I can’t wait for my turn, I interrupt people when they’re talking (sorry🥺) and I have no patience AT ALL. I do have the tendency to act before thinking and sometimes, I pay the price. 🤷🏼‍♀️ Also, I overthink everything and I have difficulty falling asleep. 
I’m a emotional roller-coaster, I cry over everything and I have empathy for everyone.
So many people would say that these traits are negative but in my opinion, that’s what make me unique. I’m filled with warmth, emotion and authenticity. ❤️

👇🏼Comment below: What ADHD traits make(s) you unique?
Also, feel free to add symptoms that aren’t listed here!

Source: MayoClinic | Healthline

✨ Follow @what.is.mental.illness for 
more mental health tools & resources 
_________________

node.text:
Put a 💙 in the comments if saying no is hard for you👇🏼

Hit the button SAVE 📩 for later & omment below your favorite alternatives! ☺️

WHY SAYING NO IS DIFFICULT BUT IMPORTANT
Saying “no” can be really difficult because you don’t want to upset people. You might be worried about what they will think of you or how they will react. Maybe you’ll lose their favor.

I know, I’ve had this problem too before. Sometimes I just don’t want to say “no” because I’m afraid how the other person will react. It’s scary to think that the person won’t like you anymore or be upset with you. However, saying “no” can sometimes be the kindest and best thing you can do!

Keep in mind too that your time is extremely valuable. Learn to guard it and save it for the things you really want to do. When you say “no” to something that you don’t really want to do, you are giving yourself the freedom to spend your time doing something you really love, or maybe to be available for new opportunities!
It’s ok to say “no,” especially if you learn how to say it in a clear and kind way. People will respect you even more when you can give them a straightforward answer.

Yesterday I was looking for some alternatives to “no” since it’s still pretty hard for me to set boundaries. I found an amazing article and I thought I could make you benefit from it so I decided to create a post with these resources. Here’s the source for more :
How to Say “No” Politely – 80 Different Ways | Go Natural English 

✨ Follow @what.is.mental.illness for 
more mental health tools & resources

NO THANK YOU, BUT IT SOUNDS LOVELY. THANKS FOR THE OFFER, BUT I CAN'T. 9. THANKS, BUT MAYBE ANOTHER TIME. 10. WANT TO, BUT I'M UNABLE TO.‎'‎.

I'M NOT ABLE TO MAKE IT THIS WEEK. IT'S NOT FEASIBLE FOR ME TO TAKE THIS ON. ME IN A MONTH. 5. CIRCLE BACK TO ME IN A FEW WEEKS. I'VE GOT TOO MUCH ON MY PLATE RIGHT NOW. BOOKED INTO SOMETHING ELSE. 8. I'M NOT TAKING ON NEW THINGS. ANOTHER TIME MIGHT WORK. 10. NO THANKS, HAVE ANOTHER COMMITMENT.'.
